quizzes.explain: Never drive a placarded vehicle near open fires unless you can safely pass without stopping.

quizzes.question: When is it necessary to ground the trailer?
quizzes.a: Only when filling a trailer with explosives
quizzes.b: Only when unloading a cargo tank filled with any flammable liquid
quizzes.c: When filling or unloading any flammable liquid tank, ground must be maintained until filling hole is properly closed
quizzes.explain: Ground a cargo tank correctly before filling it through an open filling hole. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

quizzes.question: What’s a technical name?
quizzes.a: The medical term for hazardous materials used by medical personnel
quizzes.b: The name of a hazardous material most commonly used on the street
quizzes.c: The name of a hazardous material most commonly used in the trucking community and accepted as standard
quizzes.d: The name of a hazardous material used in scientific journals and texts, recognized as its chemical or microbiological name
quizzes.explain: A technical name is a specific chemical that makes the product hazardous

quizzes.question: What type fire extinguisher is required in the power unit of a placarded vehicle?
quizzes.a: A UL rating of 10 BC or above
quizzes.b: A UL rating of 5 BC or above
quizzes.c: A UL rating of 15 ABC
quizzes.explain: The power unit of placarded vehicles have to have a fire extinguisher with a UL rating of 10 B:C or more.

quizzes.question: A properly prepared uniform hazardous waste manifest
quizzes.a: is required only if there is a loss of cargo during transport.
quizzes.b: is the same as any other shipping paper.
quizzes.c: must be signed by each carrier transporting the shipment.
quizzes.explain: When transporting hazardous wastes, you have to sign by hand and carry a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. Shippers have to prepare, date, and sign by hand the manifest. Each carrier transporting the shipment have to sign by hand the manifest. Each copy have to have all needed signatures and dates, including those of the person to whom you delivered the waste.

quizzes.question: Nitric acid cannot be loaded:
quizzes.a: Below any other commodities
quizzes.b: Above any other commodities
quizzes.c: No more than 3 tiers high
quizzes.explain: Do not load nitric acid above any other product.

quizzes.question: When shippers package the material, they are trying to
quizzes.a: make it easy to identify.
quizzes.b: make it easy to open and close the packages.
quizzes.c: make it as light as possible.
quizzes.explain: The shipper have to package, mark, and label the materials; prepare shipping papers; provide emergency response information; and supply placards. Making the load easy to identify.

quizzes.question: If you are already carrying 100 pounds of silver cyanide, what precautions have to you take if you are given papers at a dock to carry 100 cartons of battery acid?
quizzes.a: Inform someone and do not load the battery acid.
quizzes.b: Make sure the battery acid is loaded on top of the silver cyanide.
quizzes.c: Make sure the silver cyanide is loaded on top of the battery acid.
quizzes.d: Make sure there is plenty of space between the two.
quizzes.explain: Acids, corrosive materials, or other acidic materials which could release hydrocyanic acid. For Example: Cyanides, Inorganic, Silver Cyanide, or Sodium Cyanide.

quizzes.question: How often have to a driver that has the Hazmat Endorsement on their CDL retake the state Hazmat written test?
quizzes.a: Every three years when license is renewed
quizzes.b: Every four years when license is renewed
quizzes.c: Every five years when license is renewed
quizzes.d: None of the answers are correct
quizzes.explain: Generally, you have to renew every five years, although some states may require more frequent reviews based on shorter license cycles. You will be required to submit new fingerprints at the time of renewal of the endorsement.

quizzes.question: The other two places where the hazardous material identification number have to appear are
quizzes.a: on a temporary license plate holder and on the steering wheel.
quizzes.b: on the back of the truck and inside the glove compartment.
quizzes.c: on all bulk packaging and on the cargo tanks.
quizzes.d: on the gas tank and on a sticker in the glove compartment.
quizzes.explain: In addition to the two main locations for the hazardous material identification number, you have to also display it on the cargo tanks and on all bulk packaging.

quizzes.question: A shipping paper for hazardous materials have to include
quizzes.a: page numbers if the shipping paper has more than one page.
quizzes.b: a proper shipping description for each hazardous material and a shipper's certification stating that they prepared the shipment according to the regulations.
quizzes.c: both of the above.
quizzes.explain: A shipping paper for hazardous materials have to include: Page numbers if the shipping paper has more than one page, a proper shipping description for each hazardous material, and shipper's certification signed by the shipper saying they prepared the shipment according to the regulations.

quizzes.question: The hazardous material identification numbers have to be displayed on portable tanks, cargo tanks, and other bulk packaging. The regulations require black _______ numbers.
quizzes.a: 50 mm
quizzes.b: 100 mm
quizzes.c: 25 mm
quizzes.explain: The rules require black 100 mm (3.9 inch) numbers on orange panels, placards, or a white, diamond-shaped background if no placards are required.

quizzes.question: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you have to know how to
quizzes.a: package different types of hazardous materials for transport.
quizzes.b: placard your vehicle.
quizzes.c: identify various types of hazardous materials by smell and appearance.
quizzes.explain: The hazardous materials test required if you want to haul hazardous materials as defined in 49 CFR 383.5. In order to obtain this endorsement, you are also required to pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

quizzes.question: You do not have a hazardous materials endorsement on your commercial driver license. When can you legally haul hazardous materials?
quizzes.a: Never
quizzes.b: Only when the load is placarded
quizzes.c: Only when the shipment does not cross state lines
quizzes.explain: The rules require all drivers of placarded vehicles to learn how to safely load and transport hazardous products. They have to have a commercial driver license with the hazardous materials endorsement.

quizzes.question: Which of the following three hazard classes need to NOT be placed into a temperature-controlled trailer (one with a heater or air conditioner unit)?
quizzes.a: Classes 1, 4, and 5.1
quizzes.b: Classes 1, 3, and 4
quizzes.c: Classes 1, 2.1, and 3
quizzes.explain: The three hazard classes that have to be kept in a trailer without automatic heating and cooling are: explosives (1), flammable gases (2.1), and flammable liquids (3), because these are particularly volatile.

quizzes.question: What type fire extinguisher is required in the power unit of a placarded vehicle?
quizzes.a: A UL rating of 10 BC or above
quizzes.b: A UL rating of 5 BC or above
quizzes.c: A UL rating of 15 ABC
quizzes.explain: The power unit of placarded vehicles have to have a fire extinguisher with a UL rating of 10 B:C or more.

quizzes.question: It is recommended that when hauling a load of explosives 1.1 or 1.3 to use the fusees instead of the warning triangles if in an emergency or breakdown situation?
quizzes.a: TRUE
quizzes.b: FALSE
quizzes.explain: You might break down and have to use stopped vehicle signals. Use reflective triangles or red electric lights, never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses around a tank used for Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) or Division 2.1 (Flammable Gas) whether loaded or empty, and any vehicle loaded with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 Explosives.

quizzes.question: Which of the following choices is a hazard class you are not allowed to smoke around?
quizzes.a: Explosives
quizzes.b: Oxidizers
quizzes.c: Flammables
quizzes.explain: Do not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used for Class 3 (flammable liquids),Division 2.1 (gases), or Class 1 (Explosives) Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) Class 4 (Flammable Solids) Class 4.2 (Spontaneously Combustible). Oxidizers fall under flammable solids.

quizzes.question: A placard is required for a combustible liquid at?
quizzes.a: 110 gallons
quizzes.b: 100 gallons
quizzes.c: More than 119 gallons
quizzes.explain: The tank vehicle test required if you want to haul any liquid or gaseous materials in a tank or tanks having an individual rated capacity of more than 119 gallons.

quizzes.question: What’s the shape and size of a placard?
quizzes.a: 250 mm oval
quizzes.b: 250 mm  diamond
quizzes.c: at least a 250 mm square or diamond
quizzes.explain: Placards have to be readable from all four directions. They have to be at least 250 mm square, turned upright on a point, in a diamond shape.

quizzes.question: The total transport index of all radioactive material packages in a single vehicle have to not exceed _____.
quizzes.explain: The total transport index of all packages in a single vehicle have to not exceed 50.

quizzes.question: The Hazardous Materials Table has ______ columns.
quizzes.a: eight
quizzes.b: five
quizzes.c: three
quizzes.explain: The Hazardous Materials Table lists every type of material that the US Department of Transportation has designated as a hazardous material for the purpose of transportation. There are eight columns in the Hazardous Materials Table, describing the mode of transportation (air, ground, water, etc.), the name of the material, its hazard class, its identification number, and so on.

quizzes.question: What placard have to be used with an inhalation hazard load?
quizzes.a: Dangerous
quizzes.b: Poison/ inhalation hazard
quizzes.c: Flammable
quizzes.explain: If the words inhalation hazard appear on the shipping paper or package, the rules require display of the poison inhalation hazard or poison gas placards, as appropriate.

quizzes.question: Whenever you load or unload a cargo tank, a qualified person have to be
quizzes.a: within 25 feet.
quizzes.b: within 50 feet.
quizzes.c: within 100 feet.
quizzes.explain: The person in charge of loading and unloading a cargo tank have to be sure a qualified person is always watching. This person watching the loading or unloading have to: Be alert, have a clear view of the cargo tank, be within 25 feet of the tank, know of the hazards of the materials involved, know the procedures to follow in an emergency, and be authorized to move the cargo tank and able to do so.

quizzes.question: You are going to be hauling hazardous materials over a route you do not know well. When need to you check the route and get the permits needed for the trip:
quizzes.a: Before starting the trip
quizzes.b: Within the first 50 miles of the trip
quizzes.c: While you are still on a part of the route that you know
quizzes.explain: It is your job as driver to find out if you need permits or have to use special routes. Make sure you have all needed papers before starting.

quizzes.question: If you are in an accident involving hazardous materials, you need to:
quizzes.a: Tell only the emergency response team about the hazard
quizzes.b: Keep all people far away and upwind of the accident
quizzes.c: Prevent a panic by acting like nothing is wrong
quizzes.explain: As a professional driver, your job at the scene of a crash or an incident is to: Keep people away. Limit the spread of material, if you can safely do so. Communicate the danger of the hazardous materials Provide emergency responders with the shipping papers and emergency response information.

quizzes.question: When there is a hazardous materials emergency. You need to:
quizzes.a: Keep people away and warn them of the danger
quizzes.b: Prevent smoking and keep open flames away
quizzes.c: All answers are correct
quizzes.explain: Follow this checklist: Check to see that your driving partner is OK, keep the shipping papers with you, keep people far away and upwind, warn others of the danger, and call for help.

quizzes.question: You need to stop before crossing a railroad grade if your vehicle is carrying _______ of chlorine.
quizzes.a: any amount
quizzes.b: 100 gallons
quizzes.c: 110 gallons
quizzes.explain: Stop before a railroad crossing if your vehicle: Is placarded, carries any amount of chlorine, has cargo tanks, whether loaded or empty used for hazardous materials.

quizzes.question: How many different hazard classes are there?
quizzes.explain: Hazardous materials are categorized into nine major hazard classes and additional categories for consumer commodities and combustible liquids.

quizzes.question: You find an overheated tire during an enroute inspection. If you are hauling hazardous materials, you have to:
quizzes.a: Wait at least 2 hours before continuing your trip
quizzes.b: Cool the tire, then check it every 2 hours
quizzes.c: Remove the tire and place it in the spare tire rack
quizzes.d: Remove the tire and place it a safe distance from the vehicle
quizzes.explain: Remove any overheated tire. Place it a safe distance from your vehicle. Don't drive until you correct the cause of the overheating.

quizzes.question: The driver have to always also carry on his person a dated certificate signed by the employer. This certificate have to also be updated every
quizzes.a: 1 year
quizzes.b: 2 years
quizzes.c: 3 years
quizzes.explain: The regulations require that hazardous materials employees be trained and tested at least once every three years

quizzes.question: If in a materials class is the word "forbidden", what kinds of materials are you still allowed to haul?
quizzes.a: Any other hazardous material
quizzes.b: Nothing
quizzes.c: You can't haul a forbidden cargo
quizzes.explain: Column 3 shows a material's hazard class or division, or the entry "Forbidden." Never transport a "Forbidden" material.

quizzes.question: When handling packages of explosives, you have to:
quizzes.a: Never use hooks or other metal tools
quizzes.b: Keep bystanders 100 feet away
quizzes.c: Double wrap wet boxes in plastic to prevent staining
quizzes.explain: Use extra care to protect explosives. Never use hooks or other metal tools. Never drop, throw, or roll packages. Protect explosive packages from other cargo that might cause damage

quizzes.question: The Emergency Response Guidebook (ERG)
quizzes.a: contains an index of hazardous material identification numbers (which is why you must label things correctly).
quizzes.b: was created by the US Department of Transportation and is used nationwide.
quizzes.c: is studied by emergency personnel to help keep the public safe.
quizzes.explain: The Department of Transportation has a guidebook for firefighters, police, and industry workers on how to protect themselves and the public from hazardous materials. The guide is indexed by proper shipping name and hazardous materials identification number. Emergency personnel look for these things on the shipping paper. That is why it is vital that the proper shipping name, identification number, label, and placards are correct.

quizzes.question: Who is responsible for finding out what permits or special routes you will need to haul hazardous materials?
quizzes.a: The driver
quizzes.b: The carrier
quizzes.c: The shipper
quizzes.explain: The driver makes sure the shipper has identified, marked, and labeled the hazardous materials properly. Refuses leaking packages and shipments. Placards vehicle when loading, if required. Safely transports the shipment without delay. Follows all special rules about transporting hazardous materials. Keeps hazardous materials shipping papers and emergency.

quizzes.question: Who is responsible for packaging, labeling, and preparing the hazardous material shipping papers for a common carrier?
quizzes.a: The shipper
quizzes.b: The carrier
quizzes.c: The driver
quizzes.explain: Must package, mark, and label the materials; prepare shipping papers; provide emergency response information; and supply placards.

quizzes.question: Which of the following is NOT an acceptable type of marking for hazardous materials?
quizzes.a: UN marks
quizzes.b: Identification number
quizzes.c: Name in italics
quizzes.explain: Names shown in italics are not proper shipping names and not acceptable, those in roman type above it are.

quizzes.question: There are three lists that drivers, shippers and carriers use to find out if a material is regulated as hazardous.  Which one of these choices is not one of those three lists?
quizzes.a: EPA dangerous materials list
quizzes.b: Hazardous materials table
quizzes.c: List of hazardous substances and reportable quantities
quizzes.explain: There are three main lists used by shippers, carriers, and drivers when trying to identify hazardous materials. Hazardous Materials Table, List of Hazardous Substances and Reportable Quantities, List of Marine Pollutants.

quizzes.question: You can't haul 1.1 explosives with?
quizzes.a: Cargo tank without baffles
quizzes.b: Radioactive material
quizzes.c: OMR-D materials
quizzes.explain: Do not transport Division 1.1 or 1.2 in vehicle combinations if: There is a marked or placarded cargo tank in the combination. The other vehicle in the combination contains: Division 1.1 A (Initiating Explosives). Packages of Class 7 (Radioactive) materials labeled "Yellow III." Division 2.3 (Poisonous Gas) or Division 6.1 (Poisonous) materials. Hazardous materials in a portable tank, on a DOT Spec 106A or 110A tank.

quizzes.question: Which of the following are necessary qualifications for non-bulk packaging?
quizzes.a: A maximum net mass of 400 kg (882 pounds) or less and a maximum capacity of 450 L (119 gallons) or less if used as a receptacle for a solid
quizzes.b: A water capacity of 454 kg (1,000 pounds) or less if used as a receptacle for a gas
quizzes.c: A maximum capacity of 450 L (119 gallons) or less if used as a receptacle for a liquid
quizzes.explain: Non-bulk packaging: A maximum capacity of 450 L (119 gallons) as a receptacle for a liquid; A maximum net mass less than 400 kg (882 pounds) and a maximum capacity of 450 L (119 gallons) or less as a receptacle for a solid; or A water capacity greater than 454 kg (1,000 pounds) or less as a receptacle for a gas.

quizzes.question: Class 8 is placarded as?
quizzes.a: A placard flammable at 1000 pounds
quizzes.b: A placard blasting agent at any amount
quizzes.c: A placard corrosive at 1001 pounds

quizzes.question: With most hazardous materials, you may park within 5 feet of the road briefly, if your work requires it. The materials that are the exception and do not allow parking this close to the road are?
quizzes.a: Explosives 1.1 through 1.3
quizzes.b: Corrosives and oxidizers
quizzes.c: Acids and poisons
quizzes.explain: Never park with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within five feet of the traveled part of the road.

quizzes.question: Who is responsible for safely transporting a hazardous material shipment without delay and keeping the shipping papers in the right place?
quizzes.a: The driver
quizzes.b: The passenger
quizzes.c: The carrier
quizzes.explain: The driver cakes sure the shipper has identified, marked, and labeled the hazardous materials properly. Refuses leaking packages and shipments. Placards vehicle when loading, if required. Safely transports the shipment without delay. Follows all special rules about transporting hazardous materials. Keeps hazardous materials shipping papers and emergency

quizzes.question: Which of the following, if required, have to the shipper put on the package.
quizzes.a: The name and address of shipper or co-signee
quizzes.b: The hazardous materials shipping name and identification number
quizzes.c: The required label
quizzes.explain: Shippers print required markings directly on the package, an attached label, or tag. When required, the shipper will put the following on the package: the name and address of shipper or consignee, the hazardous material's shipping name and identification number, and the labels required.

quizzes.question: What’s the purpose of a driver placarding their vehicle?
quizzes.a: To give people something interesting to look at while they drive
quizzes.b: To warn those with children to drive in another lane
quizzes.c: To force other drivers to stay 20 feet away in every direction
quizzes.explain: The three intents are: Contain the Material; Communicate the Risk; and Assure Safe Drivers and Equipment.

quizzes.question: You have a vehicle without racks to hold cylinders or compressed gas. You may load such cylinders only if they are
quizzes.a: less than half of the load.
quizzes.b: bundled loosely together with steel strapping.
quizzes.c: loaded upright or lying down flat and braced.
quizzes.explain: If your vehicle doesn't have racks to hold cylinders, the cargo space floor have to be flat. The cylinders have to be: Held upright, in racks attached to the vehicle or in boxes that will keep them from turning over and may be loaded in a horizontal position if it is designed so the relief valve is in the vapor space.

quizzes.question: While crossing railroad tracks, you need to _________ if your bus has a manual transmission.
quizzes.a: downshift
quizzes.b: coast in neutral
quizzes.c: upshift
quizzes.explain: If your bus has a manual transmission, never change gears while crossing the tracks.

quizzes.question: When transporting passengers on charter or intercity buses, you need to explain passenger comfort and safety rules
quizzes.a: if a passenger asks about them.
quizzes.b: before the trip.
quizzes.c: if a violation occurs.
quizzes.explain: Many charter and intercity carriers have passenger comfort and safety rules. Mention rules about smoking, drinking, or use of radio and tape players at the start of the trip. Explaining the rules at the start will help to avoid trouble later on.

quizzes.question: If a rider wants to bring a car battery or a can of gasoline aboard your bus, you need to:
quizzes.a: Not allow them to do it
quizzes.b: Tell them they must go to the rear of the bus
quizzes.c: Instruct them to sit next to an open window
quizzes.explain: Riders sometimes board a bus with an unlabeled hazardous material. Do not allow riders to carry on common hazards such as car batteries or gasoline

quizzes.question: Bus accidents often happen
quizzes.a: in parking lots.
quizzes.b: on roundabouts.
quizzes.c: on highways.
quizzes.explain: Bus accidents often happen at intersections. Use caution, even if a signal or stop sign controls other traffic.

quizzes.question: Which of the following statements about hazardous materials are FALSE?
quizzes.a: You can carry any hazardous materials on your bus as long as they are properly labeled.
quizzes.b: Buses may carry small-arms ammunition labeled "ORM-D."
quizzes.c: Shippers must mark each package of hazardous materials with the material's name, ID number, and hazard label.
quizzes.d: Many hazardous materials cannot be carried on a bus.
quizzes.explain: Buses may carry small-arms ammunition labeled ORM-D, emergency hospital supplies, and drugs that are properly labeled. You can carry small amounts of some other hazardous materials if the shipper cannot send them any other way. Most hazardous material may not be carried on a bus.

quizzes.question: The traffic light on a drawbridge is green. You need to
quizzes.a: cross as fast as possible.
quizzes.b: slow down and make sure it's safe to proceed.
quizzes.c: stop at least 100 feet before the draw of the bridge.
quizzes.d: stop and wait for the attendant's instructions.
quizzes.explain: You do not need to stop, but have to slow down and make sure it's safe, when: there is a traffic light showing green, or the bridge has an attendant or traffic officer who controls traffic whenever the bridge opens

quizzes.question: Your bus is disabled. The bus, with riders aboard, may be towed or pushed to a safe place only:
quizzes.a: By another bus with its 4-way flashers on
quizzes.b: By a tow truck with a GVWR of at least 27,000 pounds
quizzes.c: If the distance is less than 1 mile
quizzes.d: If getting off the bus would be riskier for the riders
quizzes.explain: Do not tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle, unless getting off would be unsafe. Only tow or push the bus to the nearest safe spot to discharge passengers.

quizzes.question: How are buses to handle most railroad grade crossings?
quizzes.a: Come to a complete stop before crossing
quizzes.b: Slow down and prepare to stop if a train is approaching
quizzes.c: Turn the vehicle flashers on before crossing
quizzes.d: Tap the electric horn before crossing
quizzes.explain: Stop your bus between 15 and 50 feet before railroad crossings. Listen and look in both directions for trains.

quizzes.question: All the following need to be in good working order before driving. Which item have to be in good working order before the bus can leave?
quizzes.a: Destination sign
quizzes.b: Service brakes
quizzes.c: Rest room service
quizzes.explain: The service brake need to be tested and in working order before leaving.

quizzes.question: According to federal regulations, the minimum depth required for tire tread on steering axle tires is _____ of an inch.
quizzes.explain: The minimum tread depth for commercial vehicles on the front or steer axel is 4/32 of an inch.

quizzes.question: Which of the following statements are true?
quizzes.a: You can tow a disabled bus with passengers aboard only to the nearest safe spot to let them off.
quizzes.b: You can tow a disabled bus with riders aboard only if it's dangerous for riders to get off.
quizzes.c: Both of the above are true.
quizzes.d: Neither of the above is true.
quizzes.explain: Do not tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle, unless getting off would be unsafe. Only tow or push the bus to the nearest safe spot to discharge passengers.

quizzes.question: Commercial bus drivers have to have a CDL if:
quizzes.a: They drive a vehicle that is designed to carry more than nine passengers
quizzes.b: They drive a vehicle that has a gross weight rating of more than 26,000 pounds
quizzes.c: They drive a vehicle that is designed to carry more than sixteen passengers including the driver
quizzes.explain: You have to have a CDL to operate a vehicle designed to transport 16 or more passengers including the driver.

quizzes.question: Federal regulations do not allow a driver to drive if he or she is:
quizzes.a: Ill or impaired, and the condition interferes with the ability to drive safely
quizzes.b: Ill for longer than three hours
quizzes.c: Taking medication of any kind
quizzes.explain: If it interferes with the ability to drive safe, you will not be allowed to drive.

quizzes.question: In general, the best braking technique to use in maintaining a safe speed when driving on a downgrade is:
quizzes.a: Fanning or pumping the brakes
quizzes.b: Using only the parking brakes
quizzes.c: Use the snub braking method
quizzes.explain: Snub braking involves applying the brakes firmly enough to feel a definite slowing down which reduces your speed by 5 mph in about 3 seconds and then releasing the brakes climbing back up to your safe speed, and then repeat.

quizzes.question: If your bus becomes disabled on a freeway or expressway and you have to stop on the left side of the road, it is best to stop so that the bus is:
quizzes.a: In line with traffic, against the farthest left wall divider, or line
quizzes.b: In line with traffic and centered between the left edge of the shoulder and the left edge of traffic
quizzes.c: At an angle to traffic with the front door facing the downstream side of traffic
quizzes.explain: You need to stop at an angle with your door facing the downstream (cars that have already passed) side of traffic.

quizzes.question: Which seats have to be equipped with a seat belt?
quizzes.a: The driver's seat
quizzes.b: Side seats
quizzes.c: Neither of the above
quizzes.explain: The driver's seat in every bus have to be equipped with a seat belt in good working order. Always wear your seat belt whenever your bus is in motion.

quizzes.question: The posted speed on a curve is
quizzes.a: safe for cars in good weather.
quizzes.b: safe for buses in good weather.
quizzes.c: safe for cars and buses in bad weather.
quizzes.explain: In good weather, the posted speed is safe for cars, but it may be too high for many buses. With good traction, the bus may roll over; with poor traction, it might slide off the curve.

quizzes.question: You may sometimes haul small arms ammunition, emergency shipments of drugs, or hospital supplies on a bus. The total weight of all such hazardous materials have to not be greater than _____ pounds.
quizzes.explain: A bus cannot carry more than 500 pounds total of allowed hazardous materials, and no more than 100 pounds of any one class.

quizzes.question: Charter bus drivers need to
quizzes.a: allow riders to drink and smoke on the bus.
quizzes.b: have conversations with passengers.
quizzes.c: remind riders to take carry-ons with them whenever they get off the bus.
quizzes.d: allow riders on the bus before departure time.
quizzes.explain: Remind riders to take carry-ons with them if they get off the bus.

quizzes.question: If you have riders aboard, you have to never fuel your bus:
quizzes.a: With a higher grade of fuel
quizzes.b: In a closed building
quizzes.c: Without a static chain
quizzes.d: With any of the windows open
quizzes.explain: Avoid fueling your bus with riders on board unless absolutely necessary. Never refuel in a closed building with riders on board.

quizzes.question: A bus may carry baggage or freight only if it is secured so that:
quizzes.a: The driver can move freely and easily
quizzes.b: Any driver can use all exits
quizzes.c: Riders are protected from falling or shifting packages
quizzes.explain: Secure baggage and freight in ways that avoid damage and: allow the driver to move freely and easily, allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency, and protect riders from injury if carry-ons fall or shift.

quizzes.question: At the end of each shift you need to:
quizzes.a: Inspect your bus
quizzes.b: Report any defects
quizzes.c: Take all your personal belongings
quizzes.explain: At the end of your shift you need to do your post trip inspection, reporting any defects or repairs needed, and take all of your personal belongings.

quizzes.question: When the roads are slippery you need to?
quizzes.a: Add one more second to your following distance
quizzes.b: Keep much more space than in ideal driving conditions
quizzes.c: Keep the same amount of space
quizzes.explain: With slippery roads you need to keep more space in front of your vehicle while driving compared to ideal conditions.

quizzes.question: Prohibited practices on the bus include:
quizzes.a: Fueling your bus with riders on board
quizzes.b: Talking  with riders while driving
quizzes.c: Towing a disabled bus
quizzes.explain: Avoid fueling your bus with riders on board unless absolutely necessary, never refuel in a closed building with riders on board, don't talk with riders or engage in any other distracting activity while driving, and do not tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle unless getting off would be unsafe.

quizzes.question: When arriving at the destination announce:
quizzes.a: The location and departure time
quizzes.b: The reason for stopping
quizzes.c: All answers are correct
quizzes.explain: When arriving at the destination or intermediate stops announce: the location, reason for stopping, next departure time, and bus number.

quizzes.question: Before you start to drive, you have to inspect all of the following EXCEPT
quizzes.a: the steering mechanism.
quizzes.b: the AM/FM radio.
quizzes.c: the parking brake.
quizzes.explain: Before you start to drive, you have to check all the critical systems such as steering, brakes, tires, and emergency equipment to be sure they work properly. For the passengers' safety, you have to also check such interior items as seats, handholds, railings, signaling devices, and emergency exits

quizzes.question: When need to you check your mirrors for a lane change?
quizzes.a: Before and after signaling the change
quizzes.b: Right after starting the lane change
quizzes.c: After completing the lane change
quizzes.explain: For a lance change check your mirrors: before you change lanes to make sure there is enough room after you have signaled, right after you start the lane change, to doublecheck that your path is clear and after you complete the lane change.

quizzes.question: When it is carried on a bus, hazardous material have to be:
quizzes.a: Labeled
quizzes.b: Stored in the passenger compartment
quizzes.c: All answers are correct
quizzes.explain: The rules require shippers to mark containers of hazardous material with the material's name, identification number, and hazard label.

quizzes.question: In general, standees on a bus are not permitted:
quizzes.a: To stand between the fixed seats
quizzes.b: In front of the standee line
quizzes.c: Within five feet of an emergency exit
quizzes.explain: Buses designed to allow standing have to have a two-inch line on the floor or some other means of showing riders where they cannot stand. This is called the standee line. All standing riders have to stay behind it.

quizzes.question: Always check the interior of the bus before driving to ensure rider safety. What are you looking for?
quizzes.a: The "Emergency Exit" sign on an emergency door must be clearly visible.
quizzes.b: Aisles and stairwells should always be clear.
quizzes.c: All seats must be securely fastened to the bus.
quizzes.explain: Aisles and stairwells need to always be clear. The following parts of your bus have to be in safe working condition: The "Emergency Exit" sign on an emergency door have to be clearly visible, the seats have to be safe for riders and securely fastened to the bus, among others.

quizzes.question: When do you sign post inspection reports?
quizzes.a: Before you start your trip
quizzes.b: Only if repairs are needed
quizzes.c: After it is certified and there are no repairs needed

quizzes.question: Which of these statements about speed management is true?
quizzes.a: The posted speed limit is safe for all conditions
quizzes.b: You should be able to stop within the distance that you can see ahead
quizzes.c: The heavier the bus, the less stopping distance required
quizzes.explain: You need to always be able to stop within the distance you can see ahead. Fog, rain, or other conditions may require you to slowdown to be able to stop in the distance you can see. At night, you can't see as far with low beams as you can with high beams.

quizzes.question: Before leaving your stop, you need to
quizzes.a: wait for a sufficient gap in traffic.
quizzes.b: start to pull out as soon as you signal.
quizzes.c: assume that other drivers will yield to you.
quizzes.d: make sure all the passengers are sitting down.
quizzes.explain: Know the size of the gap your bus needs to accelerate and merge with traffic. Wait for the gap to open before leaving the stop. Never assume other drivers will brake to give you room when you signal or start to pull out.

quizzes.question: You have to put a loaded bus into motion from a stopped position on a steep upgrade. Which of these is the best technique to follow when you have a bus with a manual transmission?
quizzes.a: Hold the foot brake until the clutch has been fully released
quizzes.b: Accelerate hard and release the clutch quickly
quizzes.c: Slowly release the clutch while releasing the parking brakes
quizzes.explain: Releasing the clutch slowly until you feel the vehicle start to pull against the parking brake, and then releasing the parking brake need to allow the vehicle to move without rolling.

quizzes.question: Which of the following have to be closed while the bus is in motion?
quizzes.a: Roof vents
quizzes.b: Windows
quizzes.c: Emergency windows
quizzes.explain: As you check the outside of the bus, close any open emergency exits. Also, close any open access panels (for baggage, restroom service, engine, etc.) before driving

quizzes.question: When pulling out of a bus stop,
quizzes.a: start moving as soon as your passengers are loaded.
quizzes.b: watch for poles and tree branches.
quizzes.c: passing vehicles must slow down and yield to the bus.
quizzes.d: you may assume that other drivers will leave you room.
quizzes.explain: School and mass transit buses sometimes scrape off mirrors or hit passing vehicles when pulling out from a bus stop. Remember the clearance your bus needs and watch for poles and tree limbs at stops.

quizzes.question: Off tracking of the rear wheels is affected by:
quizzes.a: Faster speed on turns and curves
quizzes.b: Sharper turns and curves
quizzes.c: Greater distance between the front and rear wheels
quizzes.explain: Off tracking can be changed by speed, the sharpness of the turn, and the distance between the front and rear wheels.

quizzes.question: The interlock system for the brake and accelerator on a transit coach may be used:
quizzes.a: To replace the parking brake
quizzes.b: To replace the rear door emergency buzzer
quizzes.c: As a safety feature when the exit door is open
quizzes.explain: Urban mass transit coaches may have a brake and accelerator interlock system. The interlock applies the brakes and holds the throttle in idle position when the rear door is open, releasing when the door is closed. Do not use this safety feature in place of the parking brake.

quizzes.question: Which of these statements about speed management and braking is true?
quizzes.a: You need about four times as much braking distance at 40 mph as at 20 mph.
quizzes.b: The total stopping distance of a bus is the distance it takes to stop once the brakes are applied.
quizzes.c: Stopping time increases by one second for each 10 mph over 20 mph.
quizzes.d: The posted speed limit will always allow you to stop safely.
quizzes.explain: When you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph the impact is 4 times greater. The braking distance is also 4 times longer.

quizzes.question: Rules require shippers to mark containers of hazardous materials with:
quizzes.a: Materials name
quizzes.b: ID number and hazard label
quizzes.c: All answers are correct
quizzes.explain: The rules require shippers to mark containers of hazardous material with the material's name, identification number, and hazard label.

quizzes.question: The driver's seat need to be adjusted:
quizzes.a: Only when the bus is at a stop
quizzes.b: Only when the bus is moving at 30 MPH or less
quizzes.c: Whenever the driver finds it necessary while driving
quizzes.explain: Seat adjustments need to only be made when the vehicle is stopped.

quizzes.question: You do not have to stop _________, but you have to slow down and check for other vehicles.
quizzes.a: when a flag person (flagger) signals you to stop
quizzes.b: at a railroad crossing
quizzes.c: at a red light
quizzes.explain: You do not have to stop but have to slow down and carefully check for other vehicles: at streetcar crossings, where a policeman or flagman is directing traffic, if a traffic signal is green, and at crossings marked as "exempt" or "abandoned."

quizzes.question: To prevent theft and vandalism on a charter bus,
quizzes.a: make frequent stops to check on the bus's interior.
quizzes.b: collect all the valuables from the passengers.
quizzes.c: do not allow riders on the bus until departure time.
quizzes.explain: Charter bus drivers need to not allow riders on the bus until departure time. This will help prevent theft or vandalism of the bus.

quizzes.question: You have passed all the requirements for a class B bus driver's license.  Which of these vehicles are you not license to drive?
quizzes.a: Class A bus
quizzes.b: Class B bus
quizzes.c: Class C bus

quizzes.question: You have to stop your bus between:
quizzes.a: 15 to 50 feet before a railroad crossing
quizzes.b: 5 to 10 feet before a railroad crossing
quizzes.c: 20 to 25 feet before a railroad crossing
quizzes.explain: Stop your bus between 15 and 50 feet before railroad crossings. Listen and look in both directions for trains.

quizzes.question: Which of the following answers lists the three types of emergency equipment you have to have on your bus?
quizzes.a: Emergency reflectors, fire extinguisher, signal flares and tire repair kit
quizzes.b: Hydraulic jack, fire extinguisher, signal flares
quizzes.c: Fire extinguisher, spare electrical fuses, and emergency reflectors
quizzes.explain: You have to have a fire extinguisher 10 BC or better, spare electrical fuses, and emergency reflective triangles.

quizzes.question: Federal regulations set an axle weight limit of _____ pounds on a tandem axle that is four feet apart.
quizzes.explain: Federal law states that single axles are limited to 20,000 pounds, and axles spaced more than 40 inches and not more than 96 inches apart (tandem axles) are limited to 34,000 pounds.

quizzes.question: When have to a driver's inspection report be completed?
quizzes.a: At the start of every trip
quizzes.b: At the end of every work day
quizzes.c: At every duty status change
quizzes.explain: Drivers inspections repots have to be completed at the end of every working day.

quizzes.question: It is best to wear your seat belt:
quizzes.a: Only when you will be driving over 35 MPH
quizzes.b: Only when driving on sand, gravel, or ice-covered roads
quizzes.c: always
quizzes.explain: The driver's seat need to have a seat belt. Always use it for safety.

quizzes.question: You need to evacuate your bus in an emergency, passengers need to be directed to a safe place no less than _____ feet from the bus.
quizzes.explain: Passengers need to be moved at least 100 feet from the bus.

quizzes.question: As the driver of a bus, how can you best avoid hindering other traffic on the highway?
quizzes.a: By driving slightly faster than the other traffic
quizzes.b: By passing only the slowest vehicles
quizzes.c: By traveling in convoy packs with other heavy vehicles
quizzes.d: By staying in the right-hand lane
quizzes.explain: Staying to the right side of the road will reduce the effect of the buss on traffic.

quizzes.question: The standee line is:
quizzes.a: A two-inch line on the floor to the rear of the driver's seat
quizzes.b: There is no such thing on a bus
quizzes.c: A two-inch line dividing the aisle in half
quizzes.explain: Buses designed to allow standing have to have a two-inch line on the floor or some other means of showing riders where they cannot stand. This is called the standee line. All standing riders have to stay behind it.

quizzes.question: The proper time to cancel your turn signal for a lane change or turn is:
quizzes.a: When the maneuver is complete
quizzes.b: When you know that all other divers have seen your signal
quizzes.c: Just before starting the maneuver
quizzes.explain: Put your turn signal on before changing lanes. Change lanes slowly and smoothly. Once the lane change is complete cancel your signal.

quizzes.question: If your bus has an emergency exit door, it have to:
quizzes.a: Be secured when operating the bus
quizzes.b: always have a red electric door light turned on
quizzes.c: Not have any signs, stickers, or markings anywhere near it
quizzes.d: Meet all the requirements listed in the answers above
quizzes.explain: As you check the outside of the bus, close any open emergency exits. Also, close any open access panels (for baggage, restroom service, engine, etc.) before driving.

quizzes.question: Which of the following statements about the roof hatches is true?
quizzes.a: You may not leave the roof hatches open at any time.
quizzes.b: Always leave the roof hatches partly open.
quizzes.c: You can lock the roof hatches in a partly open position for fresh air.
quizzes.d: The bus has lower clearance when the roof hatches are open.
quizzes.explain: You may lock some emergency roof hatches in a partly open position for fresh air. Do not leave them open as a regular practice. Keep in mind the bus's higher clearance while driving with them open.

quizzes.question: Which of these is the best general rule for night driving?
quizzes.a: Drive slightly faster than the other traffic
quizzes.b: Drive slightly slower than the other traffic
quizzes.c: Increase the normal daytime following distance by one second
quizzes.explain: Adding an extra second in your normal daytime following distance would be the safest option.

quizzes.question: When driving at more than 40 mph, what is the safe minimum following distance for ideal daytime conditions?
quizzes.a: One second for every 10 feet of vehicle length rounded upward
quizzes.b: One second for every 10 feet of vehicle length rounded upward plus one second
quizzes.c: Four seconds
quizzes.explain: One good rule says you need at least one second for each 10 feet of vehicle length at speeds below 40 mph. At greater speeds, you have to add 1 second for safety.

quizzes.question: If your bus leans toward the outside on a banked curve, you are:
quizzes.a: Driving too slowly
quizzes.b: Driving on a wet surface
quizzes.c: Driving at the correct speed
quizzes.explain: If your bus leans toward the outside on a banked curve, you are driving too fast.

quizzes.question: Which of these is a good rule for backing a straight bus?
quizzes.a: Back toward the side opposite the driver
quizzes.b: Turn the steering wheel away from the direction in which you want the back of the vehicle to go
quizzes.c: Use voice signals to communicate with a helper
quizzes.explain: Because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle, backing is always dangerous. Avoid backing whenever you can. When you have to back, here are a few simple safety rules: start in the proper position, look at your path, use mirrors on both sides, back slowly, back and turn toward the driver's side whenever possible, and use a helper whenever possible.

quizzes.question: Buses may carry
quizzes.a: Class 1 poison
quizzes.b: Explosives
quizzes.c: Small arms ammunition labeled ORM-D
quizzes.explain: Buses may carry small-arms ammunition labeled ORM-D, emergency hospital supplies, and drugs.

quizzes.question: Charter drivers need to:
quizzes.a: Not allow riders on the bus until departure time
quizzes.b: Mention and explain the rules
quizzes.c: All answers are correct
quizzes.explain: When driving a charter, you need to load passengers right before departure, and explain the rules once they have boarded.

quizzes.question: An oncoming vehicle keeps its high beams on. You need to deal with this hazard by:
quizzes.a: Turning your high beams on
quizzes.b: Putting down your visors to block the beams
quizzes.c: Blinking your trailer or side lights
quizzes.d: Looking to the right side of your lane
quizzes.explain: Do not look directly at lights of oncoming vehicles. Look slightly to the right at a right lane or edge marking, if available.

quizzes.question: How many folding aisle seats are allowed in a bus?
quizzes.explain: Folding aisle seats are not allowed on passenger busses.

quizzes.question: If you are performing your vehicle inspection test on a coach or transit bus, you will have to inspect the baggage compartments and make sure that the baggage compartment doors ________ securely.
quizzes.a: open
quizzes.b: lift
quizzes.c: close
quizzes.explain: As you check the outside of the bus, close any open emergency exits. Also, close any open access panels (for baggage, restroom service, engine, etc.) before driving, and make sure all are latched properly.

quizzes.question: A straight vehicle weighing 20,000 pounds which hauls 20 passengers falls into which CDL class:
quizzes.a: A
quizzes.b: B
quizzes.c: C
quizzes.explain: A vehicle with no articulation (Class A has articulation), weighing less than 26,001 pounds (Class B is 26,001 or more) would fall under Class C.

quizzes.question: If a passenger is drunk or disruptive, you may
quizzes.a: follow your carrier's guidelines for dealing with unruly passengers.
quizzes.b: drop the person off in a safe, well-lit public area where there are other people.
quizzes.c: drop the person off at the next scheduled stop.
quizzes.explain: Occasionally, you may have a drunk or disruptive rider. You have to ensure this rider's safety as well as that of others. Don't discharge such riders where it would be unsafe for them. It may be safer at the next scheduled stop or a well-lighted area where there are other people.

quizzes.question: Which of these forms of signaling is not recommended?
quizzes.a: Signaling to others that it is safe to pass your bus
quizzes.b: Using four-way flashers to warn of danger ahead
quizzes.c: Signaling to others that you will change lanes
quizzes.d: All the previous answers are proper to use
quizzes.explain: Some drivers try to help out others by signaling when it is safe to pass. You need to not do this. You could cause an accident. You could be blamed, and it could cost you many thousands of dollars.

quizzes.question: You have to be alert for road hazards so that
quizzes.a: law enforcement personnel can be called.
quizzes.b: accident reports will be accurate.
quizzes.c: you can help impaired drivers.
quizzes.d: you will have time to plan your escape if the hazard becomes an emergency.
quizzes.explain: You will have more time to act if you see hazards before they become emergencies. Being prepared reduces the danger.

quizzes.question: Can a bus carry 100 pounds each of class 1, class 3, class 4, and class 5 hazardous materials?
quizzes.a: Yes, but only for short distances.
quizzes.b: Yes, but only at night.
quizzes.c: No.
quizzes.explain: Passenger buses can carry up to 100 pounds of each class of hazardous materials and up to 500 pounds total. However, there are some exceptions. Division 2.3 (poison gas) and liquid Class 6 (poison) cannot be carried in any amounts. Explosives and radioactive cannot be carried in the passenger area.

quizzes.question: no defects are listed on it.
quizzes.a: you have personally witnessed all the defects listed on the report being repaired.
quizzes.b: you know the previous driver personally and trust him or her.
quizzes.c: the defects listed on it have been certified as either repaired or not needing to be repaired.

quizzes.question: When you are not sure who has the right of way, the safest course of action is to:
quizzes.a: Let the vehicle on the right have the right of way
quizzes.b: Let whoever got there first have the right of way
quizzes.c: Let the other driver have the right of way
quizzes.explain: When in doubt be courteous and allow the other driver the right of way.

quizzes.question: When stopping for railroad tracks, you have to stop no closer than how many feet before the nearest track?
quizzes.explain: You have to stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest rail at a railroad crossing.

quizzes.question: Which of the following statements about the interior of a bus is FALSE?
quizzes.a: Never drive with an open emergency exit door or window.
quizzes.b: The seats must be safe for riders and securely fastened to the bus.
quizzes.c: If there is a red emergency door light, it must work.
quizzes.d: If you use your outside lights, you don't need to turn on the red emergency door light.
quizzes.explain: The "Emergency Exit" sign on an emergency door have to be clearly visible. If there is a red emergency door light, it have to work. Turn it on at night or any other time you use your outside lights

quizzes.question: At drawbridges with no signal you have to stop at least:
quizzes.a: 15 to 20 feet before the draw of the bridge
quizzes.b: 5 to 10 feet before the draw of the bridge
quizzes.c: 20 to 25 feet before the draw of the bridge
quizzes.d: 50 feet before the draw of the bridge
quizzes.explain: Stop at drawbridges that do not have a signal light or traffic control attendant. Stop at least 50 feet before the draw of the bridge. Look to make sure the draw is completely closed before crossing.

quizzes.question: Carry-on baggage cannot be stored:
quizzes.a: Behind the seats
quizzes.b: On the seats
quizzes.c: In the aisle
quizzes.explain: Do not allow riders to leave carry-on baggage in a doorway or aisle. There need to be nothing in the aisle that might trip other riders.

quizzes.question: A disruptive passenger:
quizzes.a: May be thrown off the bus
quizzes.b: Should not be discharged where it would be unsafe for them
quizzes.c: Is not your responsibility
quizzes.explain: At times it is necessary to discharge an unruly passenger, but it need to not be done in an area that can be considered unsafe for them.

quizzes.question: Which of the following types of cargo can never be carried on a bus with riders?
quizzes.a: Small arms ammunition
quizzes.b: Tear gas
quizzes.c: Emergency hospital supplies
quizzes.explain: Buses have to never carry: division 2.3 poison gas, liquid Class 6 poison, tear gas, irritating material, more than 100 pounds of solid Class 6 poisons, explosives in the space occupied by people except small arms ammunition and labeled radioactive materials in the space occupied by people.

quizzes.question: The following are some situations that require special attention from all drivers. Which one is an even bigger problem for the driver of a vehicle with a low ground clearance?
quizzes.a: Backing on level ground
quizzes.b: Off tracking on sloped curves
quizzes.c: Humps or dips in the road
quizzes.explain: With the low ground clearance humps or dips in the road would present more of a hazard.

quizzes.question: You do not have to stop but slow down at:
quizzes.a: Street car crossing
quizzes.b: Railroad tracks marked as "exempt" or "abandoned."
quizzes.c: When a policeman or flagman is directing traffic
quizzes.explain: You do not have to stop but have to slow down and carefully check for other vehicles: at streetcar crossings, where a policeman or flagman is directing traffic, if a traffic signal is green, at crossings marked as "exempt" or "abandoned."

quizzes.question: In a pressurized cooling system, coolant level need to be checked:
quizzes.a: Only by a mechanic
quizzes.b: Only while the engine is hot
quizzes.c: Every 90 days
quizzes.explain: Never remove the radiator cap or any part of the pressurized system until the system has cooled. Steam and boiling water can spray under pressure and cause severe burns. If you can touch the radiator cap with your bare hand, it is probably cool enough to open.

quizzes.question: Which of the following people can remove or suspend a student from riding the bus?
quizzes.a: The school bus driver
quizzes.b: The school principal
quizzes.c: The school principal, superintendent, or the superintendent's designee
quizzes.explain: Follow your school's procedures for discipline or refusal of rights to ride the bus. If you feel that the offense is serious enough that you cannot safely drive the bus, call for a school administrator or the police to come and remove the student.

quizzes.question: When turning around at a railroad crossing a driver need to?
quizzes.a: Turn on red warning lights
quizzes.b: Turn on hazards
quizzes.c: Use turn signal
quizzes.explain: Hazard lights would be required for both the turnaround, and the railroad crossing.

quizzes.question: When under the age of 21 years old a driver will be considered intoxicated at?
quizzes.a: Zero Tolerance
quizzes.b: More than .02 but less than .10 BAC
quizzes.c: .10 BAC like any other driver
quizzes.explain: There is a zero-tolerance policy for having alcohol in your system as the driver of a school bus.

quizzes.question: As part of your vehicle inspection test, you will have to check _________ to be sure that it is undamaged, operating smoothly, and able to be closed securely from the inside.
quizzes.a: the fuel tank
quizzes.b: an emergency exit
quizzes.c: the battery box
quizzes.explain: As part of your vehicle inspection test, you will have to check one emergency exit to be sure that it is undamaged, operating smoothly, and able to be closed securely from the inside. You will also have to point out the other emergency exits and describe how they operate.

quizzes.question: While looking through the interior flat mirror the driver need to have a clear view of?
quizzes.a: Approaching traffic
quizzes.b: All the students on board
quizzes.c: Open windows
quizzes.explain: The large flat mirror hanging above the driver's head is there for them to see all of the students onboard at one time.

quizzes.question: When is the only time the red warning lights can be used?
quizzes.a: Whenever there is an emergency
quizzes.b: Whenever the bus must stop
quizzes.c: Whenever the bus is picking up or discharging students
quizzes.explain: The red flashing lights are for picking up and discharging as student only.

quizzes.question: The blind spot behind the bus may extend up to ________, depending on the length and width of the bus.
quizzes.a: 100 feet
quizzes.b: 200 feet
quizzes.c: 400 feet
quizzes.explain: The blind spot behind the bus extends 5o to 150 feet and could extend up to 400 feet depending on the length and width of the bus.

quizzes.question: You MUST evacuate everyone from your school bus if
quizzes.a: the bus is stalled on a railroad track but there is no train in sight.
quizzes.b: the antilock brake (ABS) warning light is on.
quizzes.c: the bus is stalled on the shoulder of a divided highway and it is getting hot inside.
quizzes.explain: The driver have to evacuate the bus when: the bus is on fire or there is a threat of a fire, the bus is stalled on or adjacent to a railroad highway crossing, the position of the bus may change and increase the danger, there is an imminent danger of collision, and there is a need to quickly evacuate because of a hazardous materials spill.

quizzes.question: During your post-trip inspection of your school bus, you need to check
quizzes.a: whether the seats are clean.
quizzes.b: for mechanical or operational problems.
quizzes.c: for litter on the floor.
quizzes.explain: During your post-trip inspection, you need to check all the mechanical and operational systems of the school bus for any problems. Immediately report any problems to your supervisor or school authorities.

quizzes.question: What’s the most important reason for performing a school bus inspection?
quizzes.a: To give the mechanics something to do
quizzes.b: For safety as required by federal, state, and local laws
quizzes.c: To improve fuel economy
quizzes.explain: The purpose of school bus inspections is to ensure safety. A vehicle defect found during an inspection could save you problems later. Federal and state laws require drivers to inspect their vehicles.

quizzes.question: During your pre-trip vehicle inspection test, make sure that
quizzes.a: the emergency exits are undamaged, operate smoothly, and close securely from the inside.
quizzes.b: the emergency exit warning devices (if so equipped) are working.
quizzes.c: both of the above are true.
quizzes.explain: Make sure that all emergency exits are not damaged, operate smoothly, and close securely from the inside. Check that any emergency exit warning devices are working.

quizzes.question: The tail swing of a school bus can be as much as
quizzes.a: 10 feet.
quizzes.b: 5 feet.
quizzes.c: 3 feet.
quizzes.explain: A school bus can have up to a three-foot tail swing. You need to check your mirrors before and during any turning movements to monitor the tail swing.

quizzes.question: You can change the location of a school bus stop
quizzes.a: if there is a better location nearby.
quizzes.b: only with the written approval of the school district.
quizzes.c: only if all the passengers agree to the change.
quizzes.explain: You need to never change the location of a bus stop without written approval from the appropriate school district official.

quizzes.question: Properly adjusted, the outside left and right side convex mirrors will let you see
quizzes.a: at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus.
quizzes.b: the front of the rear tires touching the ground.
quizzes.c: both of the above.
quizzes.explain: You need to position these mirrors to see: the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts, the front of the rear tires touching the ground, and at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus.

quizzes.question: Who is responsible for handling discipline problems on your school bus?
quizzes.a: You
quizzes.b: The students' parents
quizzes.c: The students
quizzes.explain: Tips on handling serious problems: follow your school's procedures for discipline or refusal of rights to ride the bus, stop and park in a safe location off the road, secure the bus taking the ignition key with you if you leave your seat.

quizzes.question: You're about to unload students at a bus stop. Tell them that once they've exited the bus, they need to
quizzes.a: go home.
quizzes.b: cross in front of the school bus.
quizzes.c: walk 10 to 15 feet from the side of the school bus.
quizzes.explain: Tell students to exit the bus and walk at least 10 feet away from the side of the bus to a position where the driver can plainly see all students.

quizzes.question: When, according to the pupil transportation operation and safety rules, are the four-way hazard lights supposed to be used?
quizzes.a: When approaching a railroad crossing
quizzes.b: When stopped or parked along a road due to a breakdown
quizzes.c: When backing up or turning around
quizzes.explain: Four-way flashers or hazard lights are to be used at railroad crossings, when parked along the road from a breakdown, and whenever you are backing up or turning around.

quizzes.question: You need to activate your alternating flashing amber warning lights ________, depending on the laws and regulations of your state.
quizzes.a: 20 to 50 feet before the school bus stop
quizzes.b: 300 to 500 feet before the school bus stop
quizzes.c: 100 to 300 feet before the school bus stop
quizzes.explain: If the school bus is so equipped, activate alternating flashing amber warning lights at least 200 feet or approximately 5-10 seconds before the school bus stop or in accordance with state law.

quizzes.question: What would be considered proper procedure at a highway railroad crossing?
quizzes.a: Turn warning lights on
quizzes.b: Do not shift gears while crossing railroad
quizzes.c: Both of the above
quizzes.explain: When approaching turn on the hazard lights, and do not shift when crossing the tracks.

quizzes.question: In an emergency, you need to consider NOT evacuating students from your school bus
quizzes.a: if their injuries might be worsened by moving them.
quizzes.b: if they would be exposed to downed power lines or other hazards.
quizzes.c: in either of the above situations.
quizzes.explain: A decision to evacuate need to include consideration of the following conditions: fire or danger of fire; smell of raw or leaking fuel; the chance the bus could be hit by other vehicles; downed power lines;  exposing students to speeding traffic, severe weather, or a dangerous environment; when moving a student complicate injury; or a hazardous spill.

quizzes.question: After you decide on the best type of evacuation, what have to you do next?
quizzes.a: Notify the dispatch office of the evacuation.
quizzes.b: Dangle the radio telephone or microphone out of the driver's window for later use.
quizzes.c: Secure the bus.
quizzes.explain: Secure the bus by: Placing transmission in Park, setting parking brakes, shut off the engine, remove ignition key, and activate hazard-warning lights.

quizzes.question: In flat mirrors you need to see?
quizzes.a: Full side of the bus and rear of bus
quizzes.b: 200 feet behind
quizzes.c: Pedestrians on the side walk on both sides of the bus
quizzes.explain: Ensure that the flat mirrors are properly adjusted so you can see: 200 feet or 4 bus lengths behind the bus, along the sides of the bus, and the rear tires touching the ground.

quizzes.question: Which of the following statements about evacuation procedures is true?
quizzes.a: If time allows, notify the dispatch office about your situation, your location, and the type of assistance you need.
quizzes.b: If time allows, back up to a safe location before evacuating the bus.
quizzes.c: If time allows, walk through the bus and close all the windows.
quizzes.explain: If time allows, notify dispatch office of evacuation location, conditions, and type of assistance needed.

quizzes.question: When approaching a bus stop on a multilane roadway, you need to maintain your position _________ of the rightmost lane.
quizzes.a: toward the right edge
quizzes.b: toward the left edge
quizzes.c: in the center
quizzes.explain: Move as far as possible to the right on the traveled portion of the roadway.

quizzes.question: When unloading students at a school, you need to
quizzes.a: stand outside the bus in front of a crossover mirror to supervise unloading.
quizzes.b: leave the engine running so you can drive away when the students have exited.
quizzes.c: tell the students to remain seated until they are told to exit.
quizzes.explain: Have the students remain seated until told to exit.

quizzes.question: Immediately after stopping, you need to first
quizzes.a: activate the alternating flashing amber lights.
quizzes.b: activate the alternating flashing red lights and ensure that the stop arm is extended.
quizzes.c: load the students as quickly as possible.
quizzes.explain: Activate alternating red lights when traffic is a safe distance from the school bus and ensure stop arm is extended.

quizzes.question: How could one distinguish a blind person among other pedestrians?
quizzes.a: Will be walking a black dog
quizzes.b: Will be carrying a white cane
quizzes.c: They will only be at designated crossing areas
quizzes.explain: A white cane is typically used by the blind to help them find their way around without tripping.

quizzes.question: Why is it so critical for you to understand the loading and unloading procedures?
quizzes.a: Because drivers tend to ignore students walking to school
quizzes.b: Because only high school students understand how to cross the road
quizzes.c: Because so many students are killed each year while getting on or off school buses
quizzes.explain: More students are killed while getting on or off a school bus each year than are killed as passengers inside of a school bus. As a result, knowing what to do before, during, and after loading or unloading students is critical.

quizzes.question: If a bus is being operated on a divided highway or a highway with four lanes or more which of the following describes the procedures for pick up and discharge of students?
quizzes.a: The students can only be picked up or dropped off on the resident side of the road
quizzes.b: The students can be dropped off or picked up on either side of the highway
quizzes.c: The students must be picked up and dropped off in the center of the road
quizzes.explain: Students could only be picked up from the resident side of the road, meaning the right side, they will not allow students to cross a major highway to get to the bus.

quizzes.question: Is the bus driver allowed to crack or open the service door prior to stopping to pick up a pupil?
quizzes.a: Yes
quizzes.b: No
quizzes.explain: The door needs to remain shut until the bus has come to a complete stop to pick up or drop off a student.

quizzes.question: If the bus is on fire, you have to
quizzes.a: keep the students on the bus until first responders arrive.
quizzes.b: evacuate the students downwind of the bus.
quizzes.c: evacuate the students upwind of the bus.
quizzes.explain: Lead students upwind of the bus if fire is present.

quizzes.question: While the bus is running when is the driver allowed to exit the bus?
quizzes.a: For a Pre-Trip inspection
quizzes.b: Anytime
quizzes.c: Never
quizzes.explain: If the vehicle is running the driver is not allowed to leave the vehicle.

quizzes.question: Before leaving, make sure the students are in plain view
quizzes.a: right beside the bus.
quizzes.b: at least 10 to 15 feet away from the side of the bus.
quizzes.c: at least 25 feet away from the side of the bus.
quizzes.explain: Tell students to exit the bus and walk at least 10 feet away from the side of the bus to a position where the driver can plainly see all students.

quizzes.question: Which mirrors let you view the front danger zone?
quizzes.a: The crossover mirrors
quizzes.b: The flat mirrors
quizzes.c: The convex mirrors
quizzes.explain: Crossover Mirrors are mounted on both left and right front corners of the bus. They are used to see the front bumper "danger zone" area directly in front of the bus that is not visible by direct vision.

quizzes.question: When is it required to stop a bus, look, listen, open the driver's side window and service door?
quizzes.a: Whenever the bus is stopped to pick up students
quizzes.b: Whenever the bus is stopped to discharge students
quizzes.c: Whenever it is extremely hot outside
quizzes.d: Whenever the bus is stopped at a railroad crossing
quizzes.explain: At the Crossing: Stop no closer than 15 feet and no farther than 50 feet from the nearest rail, place the transmission in Park. turn off all radios and noisy equipment, silence the passengers, and open the service door and driver's window. Look and listen for an approaching train.

quizzes.question: How far prior to a bus pick up location have to the amber warning lights be turned on?
quizzes.a: 400 feet
quizzes.b: 200 feet
quizzes.c: 300 feet
quizzes.explain: If the school bus is so equipped, activate alternating flashing amber warning lights at least 200 feet or approximately 5-10 seconds before the school bus stop or in accordance with state law.

quizzes.question: While you're loading students, if you cannot account for a student, what need to you do?

quizzes.c: Look in your mirrors for the student.
quizzes.explain: If you cannot account for a student outside, secure the bus, take the key, and check around and underneath the bus.

quizzes.question: If an unruly student is threatening the safety of others how need to you handle the situation?
quizzes.a: Move student to set closer to you
quizzes.b: Remove student from the bus immediately
quizzes.c: Pull bus to the side of the road and firmly explain the rules and regulations to the unruly student
quizzes.explain: Tips on handling serious problems: stop the bus parking in a safe location off the road perhaps a parking lot or a driveway, secure the bus, take the ignition key with you if you leave your seat, stand up and speak respectfully to the offender or offenders. Speak in a courteous manner with a firm voice. Remind the offender of the expected behavior. Do not show anger but do show that you mean business.

quizzes.question: How can a driver determine if a bus is equipped with Anti-Lock Brakes?
quizzes.a: All buses equipped with ABS systems have a tag on the sun visor
quizzes.b: When the key is turned on an ABS. light will come on and off
quizzes.c: The bus will stop much slower
quizzes.explain: Your school bus will have a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel if it is equipped with ABS.

quizzes.question: In an emergency, you MUST evacuate everyone from your school bus
quizzes.a: if the position of the bus may change and further increase the danger.
quizzes.b: if the bus is on fire.
quizzes.c: in either of the above situations.
quizzes.explain: The driver have to evacuate the bus when: the bus is on fire or there is a threat of a fire, the bus is stalled on or adjacent to a railroad highway crossing, the position of the bus may change and increase the danger, there is an imminent danger of collision, or there is a need to quickly evacuate because of a hazardous materials spill.

quizzes.question: During your vehicle inspection test, if your school bus is equipped with a handicap lift, you need to check
